awd_titl_txt: Bayesian Analysis of Instrument Noise and Gravitational Wave Signals
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in gravitational wave detector and data analysis, and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. The discovery of gravitational waves from multiple black hole mergers and the spectacular joint observation of electromagnetic and gravitational wave signals from a neutron star merger have firmly established gravitational wave astronomy as an important new field. The goal of this project is to improve on our capability to detect and characterize gravitational signals of all kinds, including those from unexpected and hitherto un-modeled sources. This will be done by improving the signal-agnostic waveform reconstruction techniques developed under predecessor awards, and by developing new techniques to model and mitigate the effects of non-stationary and non-Gaussian instrument noise.

Gravitational wave astronomy is producing revolutionary discoveries that are yielding unique insights into some of the Universe's most exotic phenomena. These discoveries have generated tremendous interest from the public, astronomers and physicists in other fields, and with students of all ages. The research projects supported by this award offer tremendous opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students; the blend of creative activities associated with the development of sophisticated and innovative data analysis techniques, combined with hands on exposure in applying these techniques to complex data sets, will provide excellent training for the next generation of scientists. These skills are transferable and highly sought after in other fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The LIGO gravitational wave detectors have significantly improved in sensitivity since the first detection of a binary black hole merger back in 2015. During the ongoing fourth LIGO observing run, which began in May 2023, multiple events are being detected each week. This treasure trove of signals is providing unique insights into the astrophysical processes that lead to the formation of black hole and neutron star binaries. The increased rate of events, and the longer time each event is observed for thanks to the improved sensitivity at low frequencies, demands that we develop signal processing and more robust noise modeling. 


Under this award we expanded and generalized the BayesWave analysis pipeline. The improvements include generalizing the model used to study arbitrary gravitational signals to allow for unpolarized signals to be detected. One of the biggest challenges when trying to detect signals of unknown type is being able to tell them apart from noise transients, or glitches, that are often presented in the data. Previously the pipeline was able to model features in the data as either gravitational wave signals or glitches, and this how now been generalized so that the pipeline can model signals and glitches simultaneously. This allows us to subtract the glitches and clean the data so that it can be used by other analysis algorithms that are otherwise unable to handle glitchy data.


A new model for extracting signals of arbitrary shape was implemented as a compliment to the original wavelet based model. The new model describes the signals in terms of a time varying amplitude and frequency, which we refer to as "voices". The BayesWaveVoices model does a better job of extracting long duration signals from the data. In addition to handling generic signals for which we have no theoretical model, the BayesWave pipeline was generalized to include theoretical template based models for compact binary mergers. This new capability allows us to extract signals from binary mergers even when they overlap with noise transients. No other analysis pipeline is able to do this.


As the LIGO detectors continue see improvements in sensitivity, especially at low frequencies, the time that binary merger signals are observable increases. This increases the likelihood that the signals overlap with glitches, and makes any non-stationarity in the noise level more significant. This motivated the development of a new fast technique for removing glitches from the data, and the development of a new approach for analyzing gravitational wave data that uses a time-frequency framework that can efficiently handle non-stationary noise, while also providing a new fast techniques for modeling gravitational wave signals.


The award supported the training of three graduate students in advanced signal processing and data analysis.
